nodes.title: Article 1
nodes.summary: This partial document defines and establishes the legal basis for maritime traffic fees (shipping royalties) in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It states that these fees are regulatory charges owed to the state by carriers or maritime operators for using Congolese maritime space. The document asserts that the fees are a sovereign prerogative of the state, grounded in the Constitution, and apply to cargo generated by Congolese foreign trade passing through maritime routes. It also links this prerogative to the state's privilege to regulate access to its maritime domain and control traffic within it.

nodes.title: Article 2
nodes.summary: This partial document defines the "taxable base" for maritime traffic fees in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It specifies that the fee is calculated on 100% of the cargo transported or the maritime privilege. It also imposes the obligation to pay these regulatory fees on any maritime carrier or ship operator participating in the transport of Congolese foreign trade goods through Congolese ports or transit ports.

nodes.title: Article 3
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the legal framework granting the Congolese national shipping line, LMC SA, a monopoly or privileged right over the maritime transport of the country's mining exports. It explains that this is based on national strategy, product traceability, and provisions within international trade agreements that allow such restrictions for developing countries. It also stipulates that if LMC cannot perform the transport itself, it is authorized to collect shipping royalties from exporters, which are then fully transferred to the company.

nodes.title: Article 5
nodes.summary:
The partial document covers regulations for maritime freight transport in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The main points are:

1.  Mandatory local representation: Any shipping carrier or ship operator must be represented in the DRC by a maritime agent, transport forwarder, or ship consignee to access Congolese maritime freight transport; failure to comply leads to automatic exclusion.
2.  Submission of cargo manifests: Consignees or transport forwarders must submit a copy of the cargo manifest for ships serving Congolese ports to the maritime transport administration and to LMC for statistical purposes, within deadlines set by the Minister.
3.  Penalty for manifest concealment: Concealing a manifest, in whole or in part, results in the payment of double the amount of the compromised traffic dues for the responsible carrier, forwarder, or consignee.
4.  Responsibility for traffic dues: The maritime consignee or transport forwarder is responsible for paying the traffic dues or shipping royalties to LMC within the deadlines set by current legislation.
